131 S WINTER ST,

Re: License #: CB460360419
SI #: 2024SIC0001302
Dear Jacquelyn Marry:
Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violations identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
• How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
• Specific time frames for each violation as to when the action steps will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact
me. In any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Failure to submit an
acceptable corrective action plan will result in disciplinary action.
P.O. BOX 30650 • LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov • (517) 335-1980

Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager, Samantha Way, at (517) 243-9743.
Sincerely,
Melinda Gubbins, Licensing Consultant
MDHHS\Division of Child Welfare Licensing
701 S. Elmwood, Ste. 11
Traverse City, MI 49684

III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code Special evaluation
Title
Rule Code & CPA Rule 400.12327
Section • (1) Upon receipt of any information that relates to possible
Description noncompliance with any foster home rule, the agency must
do all the following:
• (b) Initiate a special evaluation of the foster home as
soon as is indicated, based on the information
received, but not later than 7 calendar days after
receipt of the information.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Agency did not act on potential violations of licensing rules by
foster parent.
Investigation Complainant was interviewed on April 3, 2024, via telephone.
Complainant stated Youth A’s foster placement has posted
pictures of her online, specifically Facebook. She stated Youth A’s
face is not shown in some of the pictures, but it is shown in others.
She believes the agency was already aware due to foster
placement’s employment and her connection to the agency.
These concerns were reported to the agency.
Biological Mother was interviewed on April 15, 2024, via
telephone. She stated she became aware approximately 4 weeks
ago that Foster Parent had posted pictures of Youth A on
Facebook and did not always conceal her identity. She stated
there are 2-3 pictures where Youth A’s face is visible. Biological
Mother stated she brought up the concerns to Foster Care (FC)
Supervisor in person and was told she needed to address it with
Foster Care Worker (FCW). She stated she is not aware of any
action taken by the agency upon being notified of the concerns.
Foster Care Supervisor (FC Supervisor) was interviewed via
telephone on April 17, 2024. She stated Biological Mother did
not notify her of concerns regarding Foster Parent posting pictures
of Youth A on Facebook. She became aware on April 10, 2024,
due to a licensing complaint and the assigned licensing worker
contacted her. She stated that is when she initially became aware
of the concern.
2

Foster Care worker (FCW) was interviewed via telephone on
April 18, 2024. She stated Biological Mother did not inform her of
concerns regarding Foster Parent posting pictures of Youth A on
Facebook. She is now aware of those concerns due to Foster
Parent’s licensing worker contacting her within the past week.
DHS Licensing worker (DHS LW) was interviewed via
telephone on June 28, 2024. She stated she conducted an
investigation involving Foster Parent regarding concerns that she
had posted 2-3 pictures of Youth A on Facebook that showed her
face. She stated FC Supervisor and FCW reported to her they
were not aware of these concerns until they were contacted by
DHS LW as part of her investigation.
Documents reviewed:
• Special investigation 2024SEC0001510. Intake 4/9/2024,
approved 4/30/2024. Allegations state Foster Parent is
posting pictures of foster youth on her Facebook page.
Additionally, Foster Parent is requiring foster youth to
attend religious services/follow specific religious doctrine. A
violation was established as the Foster Parent did post
pictures of Youth A on their personal Facebook.
Analysis The agency is found in compliance as there was not enough
information and documentation to support a rule violation as FCW
and FC Supervisor denied any knowledge Foster Parent had
posted pictures of Youth A on Facebook until notified by foster
parent’s licensing worker.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
Rule Code Religion and spirituality policy
Title
Rule Code & CPA Rule 400.12314
Section • (1) An agency's religion policy must ensure that the foster
Description child may participate or choose not to participate in
religious or spiritual instruction, engage or choose not to
engage in religious or spiritual practices, or attend or
choose not to attend religious or spiritual services.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
3

Allegation Foster child is being required to attend and participate in
religious/spiritual practices that do not align with the birth family's
beliefs.
Investigation Complainant was interviewed on April 3, 2024, via telephone.
Complainant stated Biological Mother’s identified religion is Norse
Pagan. Biological Mother reported her religious preference to
FCW shortly after Youth A was removed on September 1, 2023,
and this can be verified through texts and emails between
Biological Mother and FCW.
Complainant stated FCW informed Biological Mother she never
reported her religious preference to the agency. FCW stated she
asked Youth A about religion, and she reported she has no
memory of that religion and, therefore, is able to choose what
religion she affiliates with. Youth A is required to attend weekly
Christian church services, prayer in the home, attends Christian
pre-school and is subjected to religious discussions in the foster
placement that do not align with Biological Mother’s reported
religious preference.
Biological Mother was interviewed on April 15, 2024, via
telephone. She stated she reported the religion that she and
Youth A identify with immediately after removal and has several
times throughout the case. She stated she was asked about her
religion during the Children’s Protective Services (CPS) case and
stated several times to CPS that her religion is Norse Pagan.
Biological Mother stated FCW told her that Youth A can choose
her religious preference despite being 5 years old and has been
raised in this religion since birth. She stated Youth A came in to
parenting time a few times and made comments regarding
Christianity and not wanting to learn more about Norse Pagan.
Biological Mother stated her attorney informed the judge during a
court hearing and during a Family Team Meeting (FTM) that her
religion is Norse Pagan, and she wanted her daughter to be raised
the same, but the agency has not taken any steps to ensure that
is happening. Youth A is required to attend a Christian church with
foster placement, participate in prayer and attend a Christian
based school.
Biological Mom stated she had no say in Youth A being enrolled in
a Christian based school. She was enrolled because it was easier
for Foster Parent, but she was never given a choice or consulted.
She was not told Youth A was enrolled in this school for months
after she was removed. She stated she has only known about the
school in the last 2-3 months. Biological Mother clarified she is not
4

against Youth A finishing the school year where she is since the
school year is almost over but if the case continues, she does not
want her to attend a Christian based school next year.
Biological Mother stated Youth A is currently not practicing or
participating in anything related to their religion. She stated she
was told she can introduce things to a point during her parenting
time but when she has attempted to do so she was told it was
inappropriate and is not allowed to have her phone during visits.
She stated Youth A was upset during a parenting time before
Easter and made comments about Jesus, the crucifixion and
being nailed to the cross and stabbed. She stated Youth A was
making comments about needing to help Jesus.
FC Supervisor was interviewed via telephone on April 17,
2024. FC Supervisor stated the agency was provided a 5-day
packet upon case transfer from the referring agency after Youth A
was initially removed. The packet includes the removal petition,
removal order and documentation from Youth A’s foster care case
in Washington. The packet was sent electronically in 3 separate
attachments. She stated a case transfer meeting was held and
there was no discussion regarding religion. The agency was not
provided any documentation regarding the investigation that led to
Youth A’s removal, specifically the Investigation Report. FC
Supervisor did not recall specifically inquiring about Youth A’s
religion during the case transfer meeting. They usually ask the
referring worker for all of the information they have about the
case.
Youth A has been placed in the same foster home placement
since she was removed on September 1, 2023. The foster family
is part of a different religion and Biological Mother did not express
a preference. She stated the first time she was made aware of
Biological Mother’s religious preference was during a court
hearing on February 14, 2024. After the court hearing on February
14, 2024, the agency asked Biological Mother to provide
resources in order to learn more about her religion and provide
age-appropriate material such as books and prayers. Biological
Mother is allowed to discuss her religion during parenting time as
long as it is age appropriate. On April 16, 2024, Biological Mother
informed the agency of what services or activities she does not
want Youth A to participate in while in the foster home placement
or with the foster placement. FC Supervisor stated she will send
that information to the foster family’s licensing worker to review
with the foster family who has a scheduled visit on April 18, 2024.
5

FC Supervisor stated Biological Mother has expressed concern
that Youth A is participating in a religion she does not agree with
and is being coached regarding things to say regarding religion.
FC Supervisor stated she is aware Youth A has asked questions
or made certain statements about Christianity during parenting
time. Upon learning of Biological Mother’s religious preference, FC
Supervisor stated there was a discussion between FCW and
Foster Parent. She stated the Foster Parent are open to sharing
materials and having discussions with Youth A and have started to
research Norse Pagan on their own. FC Supervisor stated now
they have a clear understanding of what religious activities
Biological Mother does not want Youth A to participate in, they will
have more conversations with the Foster Parent’s. She stated up
to this point Biological Mother’s preference were not clear and
communication with her has been more challenging lately.
FC Supervisor stated Youth A is currently participating in religious
instruction or practices that are not based on her religion while in
her foster placement. Youth A attends a Pre-K program at a
Christian based school and attends church services with the foster
family on the weekends. She stated they hope to obtain
clarification from Foster Parent regarding day-to-day religious
based activities and practices occurring in the home during the
meeting with Licensing Worker.
FCW was interviewed via telephone on April 18, 2024. She
stated she was initially made aware of Biological Mother’s
religious preference after a court hearing in February. She stated
it was not discussed at any point prior to that. Once she became
aware she informed Biological Mother she was able to discuss her
religion with Youth A and provide religious based activities during
her parenting time. FCW stated Biological Mother previously made
comments stating she was aware Youth A attended a religion-
based school and Foster Parents’ beliefs and was approving of
Youth A being exposed to different religions. She stated she
provided that guidance to Biological Mother verbally and in writing.
The concerns being reported are new to the agency and has not
been previously expressed.
FCW stated Foster Parent was in attendance at the court hearing
in February and is aware of Biological Mother’s religious
preference. She stated she is scheduled to have a discussion with
Foster Parents today (April 18, 2024) regarding her religious
preference. Biological Mother provided FCW with a religious
prayer to provide to Foster Parents. Youth A is currently
participating in practices and activities that are based on Foster
6

Parents’ religion. FCW stated Youth A prays during meals, reads
Christian books, and attends church services weekly with the
foster family. In addition, she attends a Christian based pre-
school. Biological Mother has only recently, within the last 2
weeks, stated that Youth A is participating in a religion she does
not agree with. She sent an email that stated her preferences as
well as religious services/activities she did not want Youth A to
participate in.
FCW stated Biological Mother has reported Youth A has made
comments regarding Christianity during parenting time. She stated
the agency has a visitation program within their agency who
supervise most of the parenting time and submit reports/notes.
FCW stated she reviewed the visit notes, and it appears when
religion was discussed it was due to Biological Mother bringing it
up.
During the case transfer process, she was provided a 5-day
packet that included the petition, allegations, placement
information and services Youth A was participating in. She does
not recall the CPS investigation report being included in the
documentation that was provided. FCW stated she spoke with the
CPS worker a few times shortly after Youth A was placed in foster
care and does not recall him discussing her religion and does not
recall religious preference being discussed at the initial transfer
meeting. She stated the agency does not typically inquire about
biological family’s religious preference. The first occasion she can
recall where it was addressed was during the court hearing in
February 2024. She stated she inquired to Biological Mother in
writing why she had not expressed her religious preference
sooner.
Documents reviewed:
• FC ISP: 5-day transfer meeting between CPS and FC held
on 9/6/2023. Religion is listed as unknown for child.
• 5-day transfer packet: includes placement letter dated
9/1/2023 states there is no religious preference for Youth A.
Lenawee CMH report dated 8/15/2023 states “Consumer’s
mother reports she identifies as Norse Pagan.”
• 12/28/2023 USP: Religion is listed as unknown for the child
(personal profile-MISACWIS). Mom does not have anything
listed for religion.
• 2/14/2024 SWC: Review Hearing: Biological Mother’s
attorney reports that his client is Norse Pagan and wants
her daughter raised the same.
7

• 2/14/2024 text message between FCW and Biological
Mother: FCW states “Youth A does not seem to be familiar
with this religion as something she knew before coming into
foster care, so it is her choice”.
• 2/14/2024 text message between FCW and Biological
Mother: FCW states “I understand your frustration, but you
did not tell me from the beginning about your religion.
Youth A does not have any prior knowledge of this religion.
If she did, we would support whatever she needs”.
• 2/21/2024 SWC: In the car (after parenting time): Youth A:
Why did Jesus die on the cross to forgive our sins?
Parenting time worker: Because he loves us.
Youth A: When I die on the cross, I'll forgive your sins.
Parenting time worker: Thank-you.
• 3/25/2024 parenting time visit: Youth A starts talking about
the cross and Jesus died on the cross for our sins.
• 3/29/2024 parenting time visit: Biological Mom asks if they
can walk and get ice cream which they do. Youth A states
later: “We have to pray.” Youth A folds her hands and says,
“Dear Jesus, I hope you start to feel better…” After praying
Youth A asks Biological Mother why “they weren’t nice to
him.” Biological Mother takes a deep sigh and says, “Well
maybe they weren’t being nice to him. Not everyone in life
is going to be nice to us. Maybe he was having a bad day.”
• 4/18/2024 Social Work Contact: FCW met face-to-face in
the foster home with Youth A, Foster Parents and the 3
foster siblings. FCW discussed recent case related topics
as well as providing the Foster Parent with a Norse Pagen
prayer to reference and provide to Youth A. The Foster
Parent was observed to tape it next to Youth A’s bed.
• Fostering Solutions policies and procedures
R400.12314 Religion and Spirituality Policy
All children in foster care are to be allowed to practice their
religion or spirituality, when specified by their parents, and
participate in cultural activities whenever possible. The
foster parents are to support a child's religious and cultural
practices by demonstrating respect and by providing
access to services, ceremonies, and events. Children may
not be refused the right to attend the place of worship of
their choice unless there are specific safety concerns.
Foster parents must receive agency approval prior to a
decision to deny access to such activities. Likewise, foster
parents must not require a foster child to attend church
services of the foster parents' choice, nor can they require
that a foster child follow specific religious training that is
adhered to by the foster family.
8

• FOM 722-08A page 8: For each child included in the case
service plan, the caseworker must document and describe
the child's religious identity, including:
o Whether the parent or child has identified specific
religious preferences or practices.
o The family and child's history of participation in
religious practices and desired attendance
requirements.
o Description of any special dietary requirements,
grooming, dress, or makeup requirements for the
child in placement.
• FOM 722-02 page 1: Services from child placing agencies
are available to all children, regardless of the religious
orientation of the child or parent. The agency must not
require a child to attend church services or to follow specific
religious training. The agency will attempt to fulfill parental
wishes whenever possible, while taking into consideration
the child's feelings and desires. If there is disagreement
between the parents and child, parental wishes prevail.
Foster parents/caregivers are expected to take into
consideration the child's religious preference, especially
when the child has established a pattern of religious belief
and practice. Foster parents/caregivers assume the
responsibility for providing opportunities for religious
education and attendance at religious services in
accordance with the religious preference of the child and/or
parent(s).
Children may not be refused the right to attend the church
denomination of their choice, unless there are specific
safety concerns. A decision that the child may not attend a
specific religious denomination service must be approved
by the county director or designee. Children may not be
required to attend the church preferred by the foster
parent/caregiver.
Child placing agencies may not impose their religious
beliefs on children in their care. Child placing agencies
must also ensure the foster parents/caregivers do not
impose their beliefs or practices on the children in their
home. (Rule 400.12407)
Analysis The agency is found in non-compliance. Based on interviews
conducted as well as review of Youth A’s MISACWIS case file,
9

FCW and FC Supervisor acknowledged Biological Mother’s
religious preference were discussed during a court hearing on
February 14, 2024, and this was not addressed with Foster
Parent, who was also present at the court hearing, until April 18,
2024, when a licensing complaint was received. The Lenawee
County CMH report also indicated Biological Mothers identified
religion.
Conclusion Violation Established
Rule Code Development of service plans
Title
Rule Code & CPA Rule 400.12418
Section • (5) An agency shall involve the child's parent or parents
Description and the foster parents in the development of service plans
to enable the parent or parents and foster parents to
understand the plan for the child and the parents' and the
foster parent's role in assisting the agency in carrying out
the plan. An agency shall give a copy to and review the
parent-agency treatment plan with the parent or parents
and foster parents. The agency must inform the parent or
parents and foster parent that the information in the parent-
agency treatment plan and any other information about the
child and the child's family is confidential.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation The parent is not involved in the development of service plans.
Documentation of case planning is not provided when requested
by parent.
Investigation Complainant was interviewed on April 3, 2024, via telephone.
She stated the agency does not review service plans and does not
offer any assistance to reduce barriers. Biological Mother is told
what services she needs to complete; however, she is not
provided a reason behind the service referral and is not involved
in developing the service plans. Biological Mother has asked for
documentation to be sent to her and was told by FCW that was
already provided. It was later determined the agency was sending
information and documentation to an incorrect email.
Biological mother was interviewed via telephone on April 15,
2024. She reported FCW will occasionally email her but does not
10

meet with her. She stated she sends her Parent Agency
Treatment Plan (PATP) to her but does not review it with her and
she is not asked for her input. She said FCW asks for a signature
to verify it was provided but does not review it and has never been
part of developing the document. There were occasions when it
was presented to her right before her parenting time, and she is
rushed and pressured to sign it.
She stated the initial Parent Agency Treatment Plan (PATP) was
emailed to her on 10/24/23 but was sent to her ex-boyfriend. It
was not sent to her email. She stated she provided her email
address multiple times to MDHHS worker. It was not presented to
her to sign and there was no discussion regarding what was in the
PATP. She stated there was never a discussion with FCW
regarding expectations or barriers she needed to address. While
she was out of state, FCW never assisted her in locating services
or resources in the area she lived that would address the barriers
that were identified.
She stated she has asked FCW multiple times for services and
resources that would assist with barriers and reunifying with her
daughter. She stated she was willing to do whatever she needed
to do. She specifically asked about parenting classes and housing
resources.
Biological Mother stated she asked multiple times for resources,
programs, and documentation related to her case to be emailed to
her and was told it had already been sent. She stated the agency
had an incorrect email address for her from the time Youth A was
removed until sometime in March.
Foster Care Supervisor (FC Supervisor) was interviewed via
telephone on April 17, 2024. She stated prior to Biological
Mother being court ordered to complete her case service plan she
and FCW held a Family Team Meeting with Biological Mother via
Zoom on November 8, 2023. The purpose of the meeting was to
review the case service plan. During the meeting FCW went
through the case service plan line by line. Biological Mother
agreed to each item listed. FC Supervisor stated Biological Mother
has been provided a copy in a timely manner and signed of all of
her service plans with each court report. She clarified there have
been 3-4 court hearings up to this point and Biological Mother was
involved with the development of the service plans, was in
agreement and provided a copy. While Biological Mother was
residing out of state her treatment plans were provided via email.
They were either sent to her directly or included in the court report
11

that is dispersed to everyone involved with the hearing. Since
returning to Michigan the agency has provided them directly to
Biological Mother as well as including them in the court report.
FC Supervisor stated she is not aware of any treatment plans that
were sent to an incorrect email address. She stated she was
mistakenly provided an email address from the referring worker
where her name was switched. A Zoom link was sent to the
incorrect email. FC Supervisor stated that was a one-time
occurrence and no personal information was shared in that email.
FC Supervisor stated Biological Mother fled the state of Michigan
when Youth A entered foster care on September 1, 2023. While
Biological Mother was out of state she was residing in Kentucky
and Washington for a period of time. During that time, the agency
held a Family Team Meeting via Zoom, Biological Mother
participated in the court hearing via Zoom, and she had
supervised parenting time via Zoom. In addition, FCW maintained
communication with her via Facebook Messenger. It was
challenging because Biological Mother was only able to connect to
internet when she had access to Wi-Fi or a hotspot. FC
Supervisor stated she and FCW had a conversation with
Biological Mother regarding the challenges of working toward
reunification if she is residing so far away from Youth A. FCW
worked with Biological Mother to make a plan to return to
Michigan.
She stated she was gone for approximately two and a half months
which created a barrier. FC Supervisor stated they did the best
they could with providing appropriate service referrals to address
barriers while she was residing out of state. When Biological
Mother returned to Michigan the agency provided her
transportation from the airport in Detroit and had worked to secure
her temporary housing at a shelter in Lenawee County. The
current barrier is centered around Biological Mother’s advocate
who, at times, can be adversarial and communication has been
challenging. Recently Biological Mother has been deflecting and
blaming and not admitting she has barriers she needs to work on.
The agency made a referral to Housing Help with Lenawee. She
was engaged with services through Community Mental Health
(CMH) but has since discontinued those services. Youth A has
been participating in services through CMH and Biological Mother
was invited to participate in those services. The agency has made
a couple other referrals. FC Supervisor stated all service referrals
have been completed timely.
12

Foster Care worker (FCW) was interviewed via telephone on
April 18, 2024. She stated when Youth A was initially removed
Biological Mother left the state for approximately 1-2 months. The
initial meeting was held via Zoom, and she reviewed the case
service plan in detail with Biological Mother. She stated the
meeting lasted approximately 2 hours. She stated another case
service plan was reviewed in February where Biological Mother
signed it after it was reviewed, and this was provided to the court.
She stated she has always reviewed the case service plans in
detail and made herself available in case there were any
questions. Appropriate service referrals were made to address the
barriers and they were made in a timely manner.
FCW stated Biological Mother initially went to Tennessee and then
to Washington shortly after. She stated it was difficult to develop a
service plan for Biological Mother due to her residing out of state.
While she was out of state, FCW did not have her specific address
or even a general location. Biological Mother expressed fear and
concern that her abusive ex-boyfriend would be able to locate her,
so she was guarded with what information she provided. FCW
was unable to make any service referrals due to not knowing her
location. While Biological Mother was out of state FCW
maintained contact and she was provided parenting time via
Zoom. FCW made arrangements for a spot at the homeless
shelter when she came back to Michigan. Currently, there are
barriers regarding her advocates and the communication.
Copies of case service plans were provided in-person, via email
and/or through Facebook Messenger. FCW clarified that
communication is mainly through Facebook Messenger. She
stated she did not provide case service plans through email.
There was one occasion when she provided an incorrect email
address to her supervisor, but the mistake was realized quickly
and corrected, and no confidential information was sent.
Documents reviewed:
• 9/12/2023 text message between CPS and Biological
Mother: CPS states FCW said you are staying in Kentucky
right now. Can you give me your physical address?
Biological Mother provided him with her full address in
Paducah, Kentucky.
• 9/29/2023 PATP: Needs: Domestic relations, Resource
Availability/Management, Parenting skills and Emotional
stability behavior.
13

Annotation on signature line of 9/29/2023 PATP states the
document was emailed to Biological Mother on 10/24/2023.
Email printout shows FCW emailed the document.
Biological Mother later stated this email belongs to her ex-
husband.
• 11/8/2023 SWC: “Case service plan discussed with
Biological Mother and reviewed. Biological Mother agreed
to working towards becoming financially independent,
finding secure and safe housing and becoming emotionally
stable while meeting all of Youth A’s needs. Biological
Mother agreed to the CSP”.
• 11/13/2023 SWC: “FCW met with Biological Mother to
discuss her case service plan and what is expected of her
moving forward for reunification including housing stability,
employment, emotional stability and parenting education.
Biological Mother was in agreement with the case service
plan presented to her”.
• 11/17/2023 SWC: adjudication. Biological Mother was court
ordered into case service plan to work towards reunification
with her child. Biological Mother agreed to work on
emotional stability, homelessness and financial stability.
• 12/28/2023 PATP: Needs: Parenting skills, emotional
stability behavior, social support system, housing and
resource availability/management.
Biological mother signed PATP on 1/15/2024.
• 3/27/2024 PATP: Needs: Emotional stability behavior,
Parenting skills, Resource availability/management and
Communication/interpersonal skills.
• Agency uploaded email dated 4/22/2024 that included
PATP (this was uploaded on 6/9/2024).
Analysis The agency is found in compliance. Based on review of Youth A’s
MISACWIS case file Biological Mother signed and dated PATP’s
on 9/29/2023, 12/28/2023 and 3/27/2024 indicating she was
provided a copy and reviewed the Case Service Plan and PATP.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
Rule Code Staff Responsibilities
Title
Rule Code & CPA Rule 400.12207
Section • (3) An agency shall require that social service workers be
Description directly responsible for all the following activities:
14

• b) Facilitating services and parenting time for
children for purposes of reunification.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Agency is not working towards reunification with parent.
Investigation Complainant was interviewed on April 3, 2024, via telephone.
She stated the agency has not assisted Biological Mother with
reducing barriers that would allow reunification to occur. One of
the primary barriers identified by the agency is housing and
instability. When Biological Mother returned to Michigan after
Youth A was removed, she was residing in a homeless shelter.
She did not have an address, ID or birth certificate but agency told
her she needed those things in order to obtain housing and did not
assist with appropriate service referrals or work with her to obtain

• Fostering Solutions policies and procedures:
Updated Service Plans
Home Visits with the Child’s Parents:
25

In the first month of placement the Social Service Worker will
have two face-to-face contacts with each parent at least one
of which must occur in-home. The worker will also make at
least two phone contacts, if the parent has a phone. In
subsequent months the Social Service Worker will have
monthly face-to face contact with each parent and phone
contact as needed. At least once every three months contact
must occur in the parent's place of residence.
Visitation & Parenting Time
Parenting Time:
An agency shall develop a plan of visitation and family time
for each child in foster care consistent with the child’s service
plans, as required by R 400.12419 and R 400.12420 to
ensure the safety and wellbeing of the child. The Agency
shall facilitate in-person contact between parents and
children except where parental rights have been terminated
or when there is a court determination that visits are
detrimental to the child.
As it pertains to the duration or length of the actual parenting
time, visits should be long enough to promote parent-child
attachment and should occur in a family friendly setting
conducive to normal interaction between the child and parent.
If visits are not occurring as outlined above, the barriers or
factors contributing to less frequent visits must be addressed
in the Case Service Plan.

Communication/interpersonal skills was not previously listed as a

Youth A has attended several medical and mental health related

The agency is required to provide active efforts toward

Conclusion Violation Established

Documents reviewed:
• Fostering Solutions agency policy: Parenting Time: An
agency shall develop a plan of visitation and family time for
each child in foster care consistent with the child’s service
plans, as required by R 400.12419 and R 400.12420 to
ensure the safety and wellbeing of the child. The Agency
shall facilitate in-person contact between parents and
children except where parental rights have been terminated
or when there is a court determination that visits are
detrimental to the child.
The Agency recognizes the critical importance of ensuring that
parenting time occurs between children in foster care and their
biological parents, and the Agency will make all reasonable
efforts to ensure that visitation occurs. The Frequency of
parenting time must occur as indicated below:
• Newborn through age two: visits occur, at a minimum, two
times per week.
• Ages three through five: visits occur, at a minimum, two
times per week.
• Ages six and older: visits occur, at a minimum, once per
week.
• For sibling groups, the number of required visits is
determined by the youngest child age.
• Parenting time must not be reduced solely due to a child
turning a year older.
As it pertains to the duration or length of the actual parenting
time, visits should be long enough to promote parent-child
attachment and should occur in a family friendly setting
conducive to normal interaction between the child and parent.
If visits are not occurring as outlined above, the barriers or
factors contributing to less frequent visits must be addressed
in the Case Service Plan.
